content.webTitle: Marco Rubio accuses Ted Cruz of 'intentionally sneaky' tax policy

fields.headline: Marco Rubio accuses Ted Cruz of 'intentionally sneaky' tax policy
fields.bodyText: Presidential candidate Marco Rubio escalated his criticism of his opponent Ted Cruz this week by suggesting a central component of the Texas senator’s tax plan was both “intentionally sneaky” and a “dangerous expansion of Washington’s power”. Although he did not mention Cruz by name, Rubio used an economic policy speech in his home state of Florida on Monday to suggest his rival would transform America into Europe by enacting a value-added tax (VAT). As if to rub salt in the wound, Rubio name-checked Republican hero Ronald Reagan as an opponent of a VAT and President Barack Obama as one of its proponents. “Believe it or not, multiple Republican candidates for president support new taxes on the American people,” Rubio said. “Some even support imposing a new tax that generations of conservatives have fought against, called a Value Added Tax – also known as a VAT. “It attempts to trick people into believing their taxes are being lowered, when in reality they’re simply being shifted to employers – meaning everyday Americans would feel its impact through higher prices and lower wages.” Cruz has proposed to dramatically transform the existing tax code with a plan that would implement an individual 10% flat tax on income and replace corporate income and all payroll taxes with a 16% “Business Flat Tax”. The latter is essentially a rebranded name for a value-added tax (VAT), commonly used around the world but viewed with skepticism by many conservatives who see it as a vehicle for big government. According to an analysis of Cruz’s tax plan by the conservative-leaning Tax Foundation, the US government “would raise 71% of all revenue from the new broad-based value-added tax,” which would be levied on companies’ profits but not purchases from other businesses or capital investments. Rubio on Monday said the implementation of a VAT in America would mirror Europe, where he argued the government has “grown in size” “It’s no wonder that fans of the VAT include [House Democratic leader] Nancy Pelosi and Barack Obama, who called it a ‘novel’ idea,” the Florida senator said. Cruz campaign spokeswoman Catherine Frazier pushed back on Rubio’s characterization in a statement to the Guardian. “Anyone who has read the Cruz plan knows it doesn’t feature a European-style national sales tax,” Frazier said. “Instead, his business flat tax is a proportionate tax on labor and capital, it dramatically simplifies taxes for businesses, and it is more competitive for capital investment and trade. It allows us to eliminate numerous other taxes, flatten the income tax rate down to 10 percent and provides full expensing of business investment.” She added that Rubio’s attacks on Cruz were designed to change the conversation from his record on immigration. “Rather than misconstruing our tax plan, Marco’s time is probably better served explaining to voters why he continues to support amnesty and has recently tripled-down on offering in-state tuition for those who are here illegally,” Frazier said. “The reality is Marco will do and say anything to distract voters from his support for the Gang of Eight amnesty bill.” Rand Paul has also embraced a VAT, under the moniker of a “Business Transfer Tax”, but there was little doubt Rubio’s criticism was largely aimed at Cruz. The two senators are competing in the early states behind Republican frontrunner Donald Trump, whereas Paul barely registers in most polling. Cruz’s campaign has, in the past, pointed to a number of influential conservatives who have embraced the idea of a VAT. But Rubio argued that by renaming it a “Business Flat Tax”, Republican candidates were attempting to veil their support for the essence of the proposal. “Don’t be fooled,” he said. “If it acts like a VAT, taxes like a VAT, and grows government like a VAT – it’s a VAT.” Rubio also took thinly veiled jabs at the New Jersey governor, Chris Christie, and former Florida governor Jeb Bush, again without invoking their names, for backing an internet sales tax. “The internet is the marketplace of the 21st century and it’s unacceptable that anyone who claims to be a conservative would join the liberal call for an online tax,” Rubio said. The senator added he did not support new taxes “of any kind”, and would look to reform entitlement programs such as Medicare and social security to solve the nation’s debt crisis. Rubio introduced a plan last year that would eliminate taxes on interest, dividends and capital gains, lower the corporate tax rate to 25% from 35% and set the top rate on wage income to 35% from 39.6%. The senator’s opponents have said Rubio’s plan disproportionately favors the wealthy. Rubio has also proposed creating a new, partially refundable child tax credit of up to $2,500 per child, and a tax break for employers that offer paid family leave.
